title: DJI F550 Landing Gear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
DJI F550 Landing Gear was made from 2mm plywood at first. Then recreated it in 3D. Unfortunately my 3D printer is not capable of printing this yet but i will be enlarging it soon. Any advise and editing welcome. Please upload photos if you were able to print this. My plywood version was super light and very strong. This landing gear i feel is very nice because it has a space for a 4 cell battery to be mounted and protected underneath the chopper giving it a lower center of gravity. I have made this for a couple of my friends and only one has been destroyed with a very bad failure of my naza fly away problem. Lost a gopro but i think the landing gear took most of the force saving the rest of the quad copter. Went back to the laser machine re cut the landing gear and 1 hour later i was up and running again. Also build this custom box for my F550. Easy to transport with caster wheels attached underneath. I will see if i can find the DXF files and upload that as well. In cura please scale to 100. Sorry i dont know how to fix this problem. I am not good at 3d creating software. remixed_from.author: Solenoid
remixed_from.title: RPi and camera support for Printrbot Simple Maker's Kit (1405) version 2

title: Printrbot Makers Kit (1405) Raspberry Pi B+ Mount

description.text: I wanted to use Solenoid's excellent Raspberry Pi and camera parts for the Printrbot Simple Makers Kit (1405), but that design is only compatible with the Raspberry Pi B - whereas I wanted to use the B+ I had on hand - this remixed adaptor replaces the one in the original thing. As with the original, no additional screws should be required - simply undo the 4 screws on the side of the Printrbot and install the B+ mount. The screw holes for the Pi are sized for M2 screws (as the Pi uses M2.5, but I figured M2 are more common - the holes can always be made larger). The B+ has annoying placement of the microUSB power connection, facing upwards towards the Printrbot's y axis. This mount should offset the Pi far enough away from the base that the power cable won't interfere - but you might need to cable tie it down to prevent it getting caught by the moving axis. Update: Due to the annoying placement of the B+'s microUSB port, it tends to interfere with the Printrbot's y axis when in motion. While an adaptor or right-angle cable might get around this, I decided to move my Pi to the opposite side of the Printrbot to avoid the issue entirely. A new design to fit the different screw pattern on this side is now uploaded. This design 'flips' the Pi, so the microUSB port still faces upwards (instead of into the table), and the USB ports face rearwards (to wrap around to the Printrbot's USB port. Check the "bPlusHolderLeftSide" files for this updated design.

author: mattstroud

title: Personalized Soda Can Holder v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Is that chilled soda too cold to hold? 
Are people 'accidentally' mixing up their drinks with yours? 
Now you can print a personalized soda can holder! It will help keep your hands warm, your drink cold, and let everyone know which one is yours! 
I took my rotational bitmap font extension and applied it to my Parametric Soda Can Holder. This was the primary reason I created the rotational fonts extension ;).
You can customize a single line on the top ring, up to 2 lines on the bottom ring, a clockwise and counterclockwise message on the bottom, and a single line on the side of the handle. All of them are optional, so just set the ones you want.
The messages can be cut, extruded, offset, scaled, etc.
I also tuned the original file a bit by smoothing the cylinders, and adding an option to cut finger grips into the handle. I still plan on trying to smooth out the edges/corners of the handle a bit, but it's perfectly usable as is. 
I exported an example, using the name of my favorite Looney Tunes character. It's hard to see in the picture, but the inset/cut letters came out pretty good.

This OpenSCAD file requires the rotational_bitmap.scad ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6565 ) and the original bitmap.scad ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054 ) to be in the same directory. Set up your messages and export STL's for the top, bottom, and handle. Print one of each, and assemble using some spare M3 bolts, washers, and nuts. If the rings seem fairly weak (like a small gap in the middle of the ring), just shrink the wall thickness slightly (~0.1 increments) until you get a nice print with 4 circle threads that closely touch each other. If you get less than 4 threads in the circle, you may need to increase the wall thickness. You can watch the Skeinforge output to see when you get this. You can tune the OpenSCAD file to get rid of the bolt holes if you prefer to use glue. The radii were tuned for a standard soda can. If you want to hold a different sized can, change it. If you have a lot of characters in your messages, and try to use the assembled view, OpenSCAD might freak out and stop rendering it correctly. This doesn't seem to be an issue if you just test/export the individual pieces. When you compile the CGAL, prepare to wait a long time if you are using a lot of characters in your strings. I believe it took around 10-15 minutes for OpenSCAD to process each of the example pieces I uploaded here. The top ring message will appear upside down, but that's because you flip it over when you assemble the holder ;).

comments.text: Stupid question, how do I export the individual parts? Every time I try, it exports the assembled model, can and all.

title: F550 Carry box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: As promised in my previous upload here is the dxf file for this f550 carry box. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:659055 simple but really worked out great. The f550 fits snug with no movement. This is designed for use with my own custom landing gear that has allot of clearance underneath the chopper so it should work with most standard f550 landing gear. My landing gear has a clearance of 170mm plus my GPS sensor always stays attached the the chopper and it still fits with about 3cm clearance at the top. This is a all in one storage box. I have 3 chargers, 8 batteries, 8j remote control and 7" Screen all stored in the top compartment, with the f550 at the bottom. Supper clean and nothing can fall or roll around. Enjoy

Build
Cover in carpet or spray a nice colour.
Cut foam and glue inside.
Attach caster wheels to bottom and two steel handles to the side. Protects and stores f550 while traveling. Enjoy. This is a bit on the bulkier side. but for the protection its great. Its a all in one storage box.

description.text:
A collection of pieces for your favorite hexagonal board game. Irritated by how easily your favorite hex game board flies apart in the middle of a heated game? Wish it was beer-proof so you could take it down the pub? Of course you do!
If you print this, see also my folding storage box for holding these pieces- it transforms into a spinning card organizer.

A collection of pieces for your favorite hexagonal board game. This includes a set of hexagonal tiles that snap together, numbered and lettered chits that snap into said tiles, border pieces that snap into said tiles, port marker pieces that snap into said border pieces, house-like, city-like, and road-like pieces that plug into said tiles, and other refinements. Print five of hex 01 in five different appropriate colors (light green, dark green, yellow, red, grey). Print one each of hex 02 and 03 in a sixth neutral color (white). Print three of hex 04 in a sixth border color (blue). Print three of hex 05 in your neutral color (white). Hex 06 and 07 are extra, but contain border pieces to allow you to make boards in awesome, non-traditional shapes, as well as add lakes inside of land on your board.
You will have an extra blank hex and robber token in hex 03... I've never successfully derafted the robber without losing either the money bag or the knife. Good luck! Pieces have been kitted to 110mm x 110mm build layout for my Up! Mini. I've also added 2mm norkers to the bottom-facing surfaces to keep them from sticking to the raft or the plate. Cut those bad boys off with a gate cutter, sand lightly and vapor-polish, and you're off to the pub with your best mates, your dice and official hex game cards.

expanding from a previous idea,  these are 25mm caps with wall supports for standard 5mm foam core to build simple 40mm tall stories for buildings.
Floor corner caps are provided as well to allow building multiple stories...

cut 40mm x however long you want the building strips of foam core,
cut wall sections and insert into caps. in the past my similar designs have been tight enough to not need immediate gluing, but for long-term use, some glue would be recommended. floor sections should be cut 15mm longer in each dimension than the actual building dimensions for corner caps to fit. In assembly, I found that cliping corner bits onto the foam core made them great guides for the ruler for cutting...

title: Our solar system for the blind

description.text:
The planets of our solar system mounted on 3mm thick boards. All the planets are represented in correct size. The size reference is the sun (1 meter in diameter, could be represented by for example a beach ball ) The planet name is printed in Braille above the planet and the order from the sun is printed below the planet. Relative distance from sun (sun is 1 m diameter)
Mercury 41,6 m
Venus 77,8 m
Earth 107,5 m
Mars 163,9 m
Jupiter 559,6 m
Saturn 1026 m
Uranus 2064 m
Neptune 3233 m

The Braille was a bit fragile on my test print, you can edit the size in write.scad but you have to change the translate z-value in the planets scad-file to make the Braille have contact with the board. These are the two parameters in write.scad:
h = 6; //mm letter height
t = 0.5; //mm letter thickness The openscad files are included in a zip-file

comments.text: h=6 makes the Braille too small it seems. Works better with 8

comments.text: Nice work. I´m trying to understand how many pieces of anything can i do with a PLA or ABS kilo. Looks like a kilo: 1000cm3. So, if this is right, allmost 50 bottles can be printed with a singe roll. Isn´t?. Thnx
comments.author: vmspinardi

comments.text: Not quite. ABS's density is about 1.04 g/cm^3 and PLA's density is 1.24 g/cm^3. This means that 1 kg ABS = 961.5 cm^3 so that's 46 in ABS; 1 kg PLA = 806.5 cm^3 which is 39 in PLA. These densities are average, so some plastics are denser, and some less so, but on average these should be a good estimate.

comments.text: ABS is not food grade, PLA can be (depending on how it's handled and what's added to the PLA for color, etc.). Nylon (Taulman) is medical grade, so should be fine for food.
comments.author: DalekJast

comments.text: You can add Epoxy spray and wait it to cure, the same process is made with aluminium cans. (Aluminium is highly toxic) but with Epoxy gets super food grade.
comments.author: laird

comments.author: Alejoo

comments.text: I have read a lot about this and my opinion is that while PLA isn't poisonous (but who knows what dyes are used in various colors), objects  printed with FDM could never be sold as food safe.  The process of melting and extruding the plastic through the nozzle creates microscopic bubbles and voids on the surface which could trap bacteria in a way that you could never get it truly clean.  That being said, if you're just using it for water, I wouldn't worry about it.  If you're being really strict, as soon as a plastic cutting board has scratches in it it's not "technically" food safe anymore.  Just about everyone uses their plastic cutting boards for years without dying.  In the end, I would say it is safe enough to use, but it's not as safe as a water bottle you would buy at a store.  I wouldn't recommend storing milk in it.

A storage box for your favorite hexagonal game. Use the box to store your pieces, and when you're playing, pop the cover out and invert and insert into the bottom to make a spinning base. Fan out the sides of the box to hold your game cards in six separate and distinct receptacles. Such excitement!

Assemble these pieces to build a storage box for your favorite hexagonal game pieces (see other collection).
Use the box to store your pieces, and when you're playing, pop the cover out and invert and insert into the bottom to make a spinning base. Fan out the sides of the box to hold your game cards in six separate and distinct receptacles. Parts have been kitted to 110mm x 110mm build tiles for my Up! Mini. 2mm spacer pins have been added to downward-facing surfaces to allow adequate raft for derafting from the pallet. Cut these off with gate cutters, lightly sand and vapor-polish. Bond the three cover thirds to the cover core and the three base thirds to the base core (I used acetone, cyanoacrylate also works well), and snap the six sides onto the six receivers in the base. Add small (0.25" dia x 0.1"thick) cylindrical rare earth magnets to the top inside corners of the swinging sides to pull them together... this is optional but a nice touch.
For mine I color-coded the sides to the five game colors plus a neutral color for card sorting. You'd have to break up the kits to do this... I put them in the most efficient configuration for printing on a Mini. See you down the pub!

title: Cheap Ebay Crossbow Replacement String Caps

description.text:
I bought one of those cheap crossbows on eBay, but after the 3rd shot the little plastic caps that hold the string on broke (exploded). After printing a new set of caps and installing them everything seemed to work out great.   
I am not sure about the durability of these parts, but so far so good.

I printed these caps on a Replicator 2x using black ABS. Caps were sliced at .2 mm and printed with 15% infill.   
I only tried the caps that were printed upright. I noted that the ones printed laying on their back had less plastic in them (due to the infill), but they printed a lot faster and looked better.  
This object would probably be a good candidate for printing with some Nylon 618 or some other high strength material. Maybe if these ABS ones don't last i will try that.

title: Chess set derivative with jigsaw chessboard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hallo, This is a quik derivative of the Plywood chess set by ohammersmith: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:855. What's changed? I've added all pieces to one file for easy cutting, also I've created a board that fits the unique laser cut feel of the chess game. The material I'm going to use is 3mm Plexiglas or acrylics, in two colors that both give nice contrast and still are partly transparent. The chess board is only rescaled (search puzzle.svg for the original) and colored nothing else, every piece is unique so its a pretty straight forward 64 pieces and 2 color puzzle. That gives the home made chess set a nice touch. I dislike the straight and boring chess sets, this one fits my collection of weird and wacky chess sets. I've yet to design a 3 person laser-cut chess set. 24 June:
I have made a set meself, It works prety well. For my materials, I had to schrink the whole set down to 95%. The puzzle chess board work great, beside that assembling took me around 2 hours. The result looks great. I planned on designing a board outline for the chess board. and a box for the chess set. just a note to my pictures... The placement of King/Queen is wrong, because: Queen is always on its own color. Too bad I turned the board 90 degrees...

Instructions:
  • Download the files,
  • Cut et lease one test piece,
  • Use your caliper to measure the test pieces,
  • Use your caliper to measure the material thickness,
  • Rescale the files accordingly to your findings,
  • Cut one more test piece,
  • Assemble the test piece.
    • Cutting the whole set:
  • Cut the board in white,
  • Cut the board in blue,
  • Cut the Chess set in 2 colors,
  • Assemble the chess board,
  • Assemble the chess pieces,
    • Play chess:
  • Read the rules,
  • set up the board,
  • Enjoy your chess set,
    • Finally:
  • Challenge jwrm22 on www.gameknot.com,
  • Change the title to: Thingiverse rocks,
  • Lose/Win the game its up to you!
    • Do not cut the chessboard puzzle, all lines in the drawing are double. take it apart instead or use the the board_blue and board_white. Cut out chess_all twice in 2 colors. For the assembling instructions of the chess pieces view the original post of the chess set: Plywood chess set by ohammersmith at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:855

title: Greg's Wade extruder for Prusa i3

description.text:
Just use a regular nema17 motor and Bob's your uncle.   
Two things have been changed from regular Greg's, one is the motor location, that has been translated, and the whole thing has been elevated over the base so elements protruding to the back (towards the x-carriage) are now above it.  
Those of you using Budas hotend may want to use the new version with 10mm spacer included so it won't bump into the x-carriage.  
It fits the standard x-carriage of Prusa i3 (30 mm version, which is the latest).  
Based on dviejo's mod.

Source code is available, you can adapt it to any of the supported hotends. Please note a couple of files are included, now I have added them to the thing. Alternatively, copy the extruder scad to the Prusa i3 box_frame folder and the files will be found. A pair of M3 bolts (30mm or longer) will be needed to fix the extruder to the x-carriage. Video of an early version: http://youtu.be/E7ju4vxNtpI I am using a pair of 50mm hex bolts, with springs and M4 nuts for providing the idler pressure. I am told (thanks obijuan) that for 48mm body-long steppers you want to add 5mm to base_extra_depth value on the source to get additional clearance. If you need extra clearance but you already printed the extruder, or if your x-carriage is 24mm instead of 30mm, you can use this part to fix any these problems: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:81539

comments.text: If you want to assemble a Prusa i3 printer, suggest you buy aluminum frame, I've bought one from this store:https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/Prusa-i3-Rework-3D-printer-aluminum-frame-kit-RepRap-Prusa-i3-aluminum-frame-3D-Printer-DIY/1470565_32464829443.html?spm=2114.12010612.0.0.nTZP0Y

description.text: NOTE: I haven't printed all of these yet. I'll mark the tested boxes as "verified" on the Instructions page as I check them. These boxes fit the for the card game Star Realms. The Base box stores all the cards for the base set, and the Crisis box fits all the combined cards from the four Crisis expansions. Interlocking cam holder on an Ultimaker 2 for a iRobot3 IP cam

This is an offset plate to easily adjust the balance of a camera (or different ones) on a gimbal. My 3-Axis camera gimbal's plate is mounted on the horizontal rod instead of a cage so adjusting the camera (or hotshot plate) gets very troublesome just for minute adjustments. This raises the set up a couple of centimetres above that plate (but secured to it by two tripod screws) and allows sliding to the millimetre and secured in place with two small screws in the side. Other parts needed:
  • 3 tripod screws
  • 2 washers
  • Stoppers: 4 sets of M3 bolts and nuts (about 6mm long would suffice) - you could do with one on each end really if they don't affect your X axis balance, these are just to prevent the plate from sliding OFF!
  • 2 M3 screws (about 10-12mm long)
    • Steps:
  • Print base and plate (obviously)
  • Install base to gimbal plate (2 tripod screws) - Note: washers are to elevate the base about half to 1mm to allow sliding plate some free movement and also clearance from M3 screws)
  • Install one set of stoppers on base
  • Install one tripod screw underneath sliding plate
  • Install your quick release hotshot base (or your camera) to sliding plate
  • Install two M3 side screws (these are your "brakes")
  • Insert sliding plate onto base
  • Stop playing with the slider :)
  • Install other set of stoppers

title: Bulldog Lite/XL + Hexagon Prusa i3 Extruder Mount Carriage

description.text: This is a simple Bulldog extruder mount for a Prusa i3 which is based on the mount that comes with the Bulldog kit, it can be used with either a Bulldog Lite or XL Extruder. Also included is a 25mm Fan Mount which mounts underneath the extruder to cool the print. The X-Carriage which is used in conjunction with this mount is included This mount makes use of the radial fan which comes with the bulldog kit and the 25mm fan which comes with hexagon hotend kit. Visit our website for our full range of parts at: http://ooznest.co.uk

Parts needed to complete this mount are: Printed Parts of the attached STL's
Bulldog Lite or XL Kit
Hexagon Hotend Kit
2 x M3 8mm Bolts
5 x M3 18mm Bolts
2 x M3 25mm Bolts
9 x M3 Nyloc Nuts Instructions can be found on Page's 28-31 of our Prusa i3 Instruction Manual Here: http://www.ooznest.co.uk/Prusa/Prusa-Instructions-v1.40.pdf

description.text:
Okay so someone had requested that I attempt to make Lightning's gunblade into separate pieces so that maybe it can be printed in a bigger size. I had a few problems with this process as I can't really make it print much bigger in the first place if I keep the blade of the sword as one piece, so i split it into three parts instead so that you can print a bigger sword (albeit the splits in the blade don't make it very "swingable").   
But this is my best attempt at splitting this model into parts, as this is the first time I've ever tried to split a model into smaller parts.  They don't exactly fit together or snap into place, I just assume that I could glue them together or something like that.  If someone likes this model enough and leaves a comment, I could put some more effort into attempting to make the model piece together better.  
Oh and as for putting it all together, I do not believe it requires instruction as long as you reference the full model I've already posted. If you believe I should leave instruction, leave a comment! Enjoy!

This is a seesaw and track (channel) for Brio type trains. Video at: http://youtu.be/9aOEwNhrwgk Full instructions at:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Train-Seesaw/ The train will be modified and this will become the "Froggy Express" at Froggy World--hopefully to be shown at the 2013 San Mateo Maker Faire.

"railroad track a" is the key piece.  For shorter pieces, cut part of it off
The current pieces allow a 12.5 inch diameter circle.  For a larger radius, take "railroad track a" and do "15 degree cuts" on both ends--the longer the top of the track, the larger the radius.
You can make any angle you wish by changing the cut on the ends.

title: Tap or Drill Guide Block (parametric, center hole added)

description.text:
I took @Lemon_Major's original and removed the center section. The idea is two-fold: use less plastic, and hopefully also make it a little easier to align it with the intended target.  
(While I was at it, also increased the arc resolution for smoother holes. I might have overcorrected a bit, sorry if the STL file is bigger than it needs to be.)

TIP: one design flaw I noticed, is that this block is too tall for the default smallest bit sizes. That is, my 2mm drill bit is too short to even make it through the block, much less into my workpiece. So I'd recommend either changing the height in OpenSCAD when you customize, or using e.g. Slic3r by version 1.2.6 has a trim command that will let you shorten the default STL file.

description.text: Edit (8/19/2015): A new fan shroud design located here(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:974421). This new version is a dual nozzle design which has less flow restriction and also allows a 40x20mm fan to be mounted.

This is an improved fan shroud for the Printrbot simple 1405. It is modeled after this printrbot metal fan shroud (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356001). Designed to keep airflow off the hotend. Note: My hotend isn't completely straight, the tip is not in line with the upper part of the hotend. So the bottom part of the fan shroud is offset 1mm to the right (towards z-probe) to compensate for this. If your hotend is completely straight then this shroud might not fit quite right.
Prints entirely without support material when flipped 180 about x-axis

comments.text: Great fan shroud! This was my first part to print, and it printed flawlessly and worked wonders for my printer! I would recommend this part for any 1405 kit!

remixed_from.author: DarkAlchemist
remixed_from.title: Micro/Mini V Wheel Plate from OpenBuilds with Solidworks 2014 Source

description.text:
I'm in the process of building Richraps' awesome little Delta printer. I wanted to get away from using the linear rail and instead utilize the V-slot channel from openbuilds for travel along with using GT2 belts. The idea was to design an all-in-one carriage that takes the mounting of the arms and hall effect sensor mount and integrate them to the mini v wheel plate and also add a belt tension mechanism. Thanks to all that posted the following sources: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:438109
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:327862
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:471978 after some Tinkercading, here is the new system! Enjoy :) EDIT: i've updated the hall effect sensor post to have it as far up as possible and added some more clearance to the belt groove. feel free to post any comments or let me know how this worked for you.
I made some bridges in the line tension gizmo for easier printing. cut them off with a knife and to fit a longer screw for belt tension,drill the small hole all the way through.

Its an unusual way of using a 555 to make a device that turns something dangling in the air every so often.  Cheaper than using a PIC and able to run for ages on battery.  Developed by me, AJ Booker for the Nottingham e-Learning Centre. I have uploaded videos, circuit wizard files, sketchup models, worksheets, a manual plus a presentation

The PCB mask is uploaded as part of the files here, or you can create your own from the .CWZ file if you have a copy of PCB Wizard 2.0
Uses standard parts and the manual includes a full parts list and help
This project was developed for www.nelc.net and any use of this must link back to this email address please

Flashlight The head is designed to fit one of these: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Round-Aluminum-PCB-Printed-Circuit-Board-50mm-for-3-x-1W-3W-5W-LEDs/32262251814.html

  • I designed the head so that it quickly can be removed from the body without twisting the wires (and break them in the process), this is done so that i can quickly change the head so i can for example make another head with another color off leds, or a real lightbulb, the possibilities are endlesss...

  • "5mm led plate" and "head for 5mm leds" need to printed both if you want to use 5 mm leds, the led plate is made to hold 30 leds, this is done beacause:
    The voltage coming in to the head is 12v, i used 3.2v as the voltage drop for white leds, so this gives me 3 leds in series and this 10 times. (this was the most i could niceley fit on the plate)
    If you want to have a plate for less leds, just drop a comment down below and i will design a plate for you ;) (it only takes like 5 minutes to do that...)
    The plate has a "U" on it to indicate the underside, the leds go in this side (there holes are wider at the top on this side, so the little ridges from the leds drop in nicely)

  • the cone is made to difuse the light and spread it, so the flashlight can be used to light a room easly
    the cone just slides over the head.
    the preferred color is white or yellow, but you can go print in different colors to get other colors light, if you want to go complelty crazy you can use rainbow filament and create an awesome color effect
    • the electronics: 2 protected li-ion cells
    1 adjustable current usb mini li-ion charge circuit PCB (spdt switch behind the bottom cap is used to select wich cell gets charged
    1 boost converter 2.5-60v 3A (set to 12V with a multiturn pot)
    1 spdt switch for switching the light on
    3 3W cree cold white leds (in series)
    1 constant curren driver (2(ish)- 36v) (drives the leds at alot less that they are rated for to limit the heat) important note it is possible that you need to resize the part (make it 10 times bigger) as my 3D software exports to stl in other units (parts from V1.5 and up don't have this problem) changelog

remixed_from.author: Nucklear
remixed_from.title: X axis endstop holder for prusa i3

title: X Endstop holder for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is a variant of thing:649083. My modifications raise the endstop about 3mm higher than the original.
Also added material in between the clip arms and added two holes for small zipties if clips don't provide enough grip. This is also for 8mm smooth rod. REV2: Widened the zip tie holes and gave them a little more meat on the outside edges. Clearance between the smoothrod and the zipties were a little tight, so I also moved them down towards the center of the part by 1 mm. REV3: Wanted to use flat head screws to eliminate the possibility of the GT2 belt rubbing on the srew head. In order to do that I had to beef up the body a little bit. STL, Parasolid, and SolidWorks files are provided.

author: Frostbite

title: Reverse lens filter holder for ultra macro - Nikon mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Changelog:
v1.1 - Adjusted size
v1 - Inital release

Reverse lens macro is a technic where you mount your lens backward to take macro photo. Typically to achieve extreme close up shot beyond 1:1 ratio factor. Like this adapter: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:411379 by froetz The downside of this is that the back lens, usually protected in the dslr is exposed to element. And here come the solution. Once printed, take a commonly cheap 52mm lens filter, snap (or screw, glue, whatever) it on the end and lock it to your reversed lens. It's a lens filter holder... But for the rear!
You're done? Snap a standard 52mm lens cover!

Le retournement d'objectif est une technique ou l'on monte son objectif inversé pour prendre des photos macro. Typiquement pour arriver à une MAP extremement proche au dela du ratio 1:1. Comme cet adapteur: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:411379 par froetz L'inconvénient de cette technique est que l'arrière de l'objectif, normalement protégé par l'appareil est exposé aux éléments. Voila donc la solution. Une fois imprimé, prenez un filtre commun et peu cher en 52mm, enfoncé le (ou vissé, collé, peu importe) sur l'emplacement et bloqué l'autre sur l'arrière. C'est un support à filtre... Mais pour l'arrière!
Vous avez terminé? Mettez un bouchon en 52mm!
Some model are not there, you can find more here: https://www.cgtrader.com/M600

comments.text: Cool work!
comments.author: froetz
